metadata.case_name: L. S. Lalvani v. Custodian of Evacuee Properties

facts.text: Proprietors of firms Adam Haji Peer Mohd. Essack and Haji Ebrahim Kasim Cochinwala migrated to Pakistan in 1947; firms vested in Custodian of Evacuee Properties for State of Madras under s.8 of Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950.

Appellant appointed as Manager of the two firms under s.10(2)(b) of 1950 Act on March 6, 1952 (Ex. P-1); furnished security of Rs. 20,000/-; order approved proposal for management on existing system, with outright allotment to be taken up later.
Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954 passed on October 9, 1954.
Advertisement published in Press for sale of evacuee properties on April 11, 1956; appellant applied to Chief Settlement Commissioner to stop sale.

Central Government order (Ex. P-5) dated April 25, 1956: decided in principle to allot evacuee concerns to appellant; terms to be communicated separately; continue as Custodian's Manager under s.10(2)(b) read with Rule 34.

Letter (Ex. P-8) dated June 21, 1956 from Custodian: Government decided to allot and ultimately sell concerns to appellant; continue as Manager; Deputy Custodian to evaluate business, prepare balance sheets, consider assets/liabilities/goodwill, suggest instalments.
Advertisement in Press about public auction of business on March 25, 1958.

Appellant filed writ in Kerala High Court to restrain District Collector from selling by public auction; allowed on June 25, 1959, directing no sale without order of Chief Settlement Commissioner, as no such order under 1954 Act.
Chief Settlement Commissioner order for sale made on September 15, 1959; appellant's management terminated; possession taken by Deputy Custodian (Respondent No.1).
Order (Ex. P-13) dated December 18, 1959: terminated appellant's services as Manager with immediate effect; required handover of premises, stock-in-trade, books, assets.
Appellant filed O.P. No. 1438 of 1959 in Kerala High Court: certiorari to quash Ex. P-13 and P-16; mandamus for handover of possession; mandamus to sell concerns.
Single Judge (S. Velu Pillai, J.) on June 8, 1960 granted writ restraining sale by public auction.
Respondents appealed (A.S. No. 484/1960); appellant appealed refusal of third relief (A.S. No. 445/1960).
Division Bench judgment December 6, 1960: dismissed A.S. 445/1960 (appellant's); allowed A.S. 484/1960 (respondents').
Present appeals to Supreme Court by certificate under Art. 133(1)(a).

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant was lawfully removed from the management of the business by the order dated December 18, 1959 (Ex. P-13 and P-16).
Whether there was a final allotment of the business in favour of the appellant by the Chief Settlement Commissioner.
Whether appellant entitled to writ of mandamus for possession even if removal illegal.

petitioner_arguments.text: Custodian under s.10(2)(b) of 1950 Act had no power to remove Manager appointed thereunder; indefeasible right conferred by Ex. P-1 dated March 6, 1952.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950 s.10(2)(b)

petitioner_arguments.text: Order of removal by Managing Officer-cum-Deputy Custodian under 1954 Act conferred no power to cancel appointment.
Final allotment of business in view of Ex. P-5 and Ex. P-8.

respondent_arguments.text: No final allotment; terms and conditions not settled; no concluded contract.

court_reasoning.text: Power to appoint under s.10(2)(b) of 1950 Act implies power to suspend/dismiss via s.16 General Clauses Act; no different intention appears.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power of appointment confers power to terminate as necessary adjunct.

court_reasoning.text: 1950 Act provisions not repealed; Deputy Custodian competent under s.10(2)(b); order valid despite signed as Managing Officer; substance over form.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ascribe act to existing authority under which valid, not void one.

court_reasoning.text: Even if removal illegal, no mandamus under Art.226 as appointment contractual, not statutory duty; writ compels public/statutory duties only.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Duty from contract not enforceable by writ.

court_reasoning.text: Ex. P-5 and P-8 decide 'in principle'; terms/conditions not settled; no concluded contract of sale; no legal right to business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No final allotment without settled terms.

holdings.text: Appellant lawfully removed from management; order Ex. P-13/P-16 valid under s.10(2)(b) read with s.16 General Clauses Act.
No entitlement to mandamus for possession as contractual, not statutory obligation.
No final allotment; no legal right to business.

precedents_cited.relevance: Order valid under correct provision despite purporting under wrong one; substance over form.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay Presidency and Aden v. Bombay Trust Corporation Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Mandamus requires statutory duty, not contractual.

precedents_cited.case_name: P. K. Banerjee v. L. J. Simonds
precedents_cited.relevance: Mandamus requires statutory duty imposed on public servant.

statutes_cited.name: Administration of Evacuee Property Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting of properties; power to appoint/terminate Manager.

statutes_cited.name: Displaced Persons (Compensation and Rehabilitation) Act, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Relevant for sale/allotment proceedings; does not repeal 1950 Act.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to appoint implies power to suspend/dismiss.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court rejected appellant's arguments; upheld validity of removal order; held no final allotment or right to mandamus; affirmed High Court Division Bench decision dismissing appellant's appeal and allowing respondents'.

key_quotes.text: "The power of appointment conferred upon the Custodian under s.10(2)(b) of the 1950 Act confers, by implication, upon the Custodian the power to suspend or dismiss any person appointed."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on implied power to terminate management.

key_quotes.text: "It is well-established that when an authority passes an order which is within its competence, it cannot fail merely because it purports to be made under a wrong provision if it can be shown to be within its power under any other rule."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Any duty or obligation falling upon a public servant out of a contract entered into by him as such public servant cannot be enforced by the machinery of a writ under Art.226."
key_quotes.speaker: court
